awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE: Building capacity for evidence-based undergraduate field experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
Because of the tremendous investment in field stations and marine labs and the potential for reaching a broad range of undergraduates across the U.S. and the world, it is critical to consider how to best provide effective educational experiences at these venues and other extended field programs. These programs often provide specific types of training not provided anywhere else in the undergraduate education system. The Undergraduate Field Experiences in Research Network (U-FERN) seeks to understand the impacts of these types of experiences and to build a community of practitioners working together with education researchers to share and develop effective practices that are inclusive of all students. The network will connect current knowledge about persistence of underrepresented students in Science Technology Engineering Math (STEM) with practitioners of undergraduate field experiences to harness the power of active learning as a potential for increasing participation and persistence in the field-based sciences.

U-FERN seeks to build a vibrant, supportive, and sustainable collaborative network that fosters effective undergraduate field experiences by: 1) identifying and sharing evidence-based models and practices for engaging a diverse range of undergraduates in effective field and marine learning experiences, 2) identifying, modifying, developing, and sharing assessment tools for understanding the impact of field and marine learning experiences on undergraduate student learning, STEM identity, and career trajectories, 3) investigating how undergraduate field experiences may help broaden the participation and retention of underrepresented and underserved students in field-based sciences such as marine ecology, ecology and geosciences, and 4) establishing undergraduate learning experiences at field stations and marine labs as "interdisciplinary laboratories" for researching evidence-based practices in undergraduate research, service learning, and place-based education. U-FERN will build capacity of field station and marine labs (FSMLs) and others including undergraduates in field experiences while engaging new collaborators from the social and learning sciences in program assessment and research into student learning, effective practices, and broad engagement. The wide diversity of practices implemented at field stations and marine labs creates a unique opportunity to test models of effective training in order to generate insights that can inform educational practices beyond the FSML community. The proposed network will explore how insights from undergraduate experiences at field stations and marine labs can help improve undergraduate STEM teaching and learning in general.

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO), Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources (EHR), Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange.or/finalreport/). This project is also co-funded by the Division of Environmental Biology (DEB) in the BIO directorate.

por.por_cntn:
The RCN-UBE: Building capacity for evidence-based undergraduate field experiences Undergraduate-Field Experiences Research Network (UFERN) project developed an interdisciplinary, collaborative, and lasting network focused on fostering inclusive and accessible undergraduate field experiences (UFEs). Specifically, UFERN identified, developed, and shared evidence-based models and practices and assessment tools for supporting UFEs to be more inclusive and also catalyzed research on student learning in UFEs.

Through network meetings, sharing of resources, and working on collaborative products, UFERN developed an interdisciplinary network that engaged participants who are STEM education researchers (i.e., social and behavioral scientists who work in place-based education, undergraduate STEM education, learning sciences, education psychology or related fields) and UFE instructors (i.e., faculty or other educators leading STEM- and field-based undergraduate research experiences, field courses or other similar programs). For most participants, the STEM focus was ecology and environmental science, but disciplinary backgrounds also include geoscience, archeology, and marine science.

The project's intellectual merit is that UFERN catalyzed research on student learning and contributed findings to the broader body of evidence about undergraduate STEM learning. For example, early in the project, a landscape study led to a broader understanding of how UFEs are designed, implemented and assessed across both ecology and the environmental sciences and geosciences. This paper (O'Connell et al. 2020) garnered much interest; it was one of the 10 top-cited articles in the last three years in the Journal of Geoscience Education.  UFERN also synthesized and highlighted research about affective outcomes (e.g., interest, belonging, motivation) in UFEs through a lightning session at the 2021 network meeting and a collaborative meeting report (Ward et al. 2021).

The flagship synthetic product, the UFERN model (O'Connell et al. 2022), provides a holistic picture of learning and personal development in UFEs. Using specific research on UFEs, general research on STEM education, and the expertise and experience of both educators and researchers in the UFERN community, we created a model that describes the impact of student context factors and program design factors on student outcomes in a variety of formats of UFEs. Further research is needed to identify causal mechanisms leading to the efficacy of UFEs and explore which elements of these experiences lead to which intended student outcomes for which students across UFE formats and disciplines. The UFERN model provides the foundation to do this research in the future.

The broader impacts of UFERN are in the resources and professional development that support field educators in designing, implementing and assessing more inclusive and accessible UFEs. Interdisciplinary collaborations within the network led to resources and enduring products that can be accessed on the UFERN website (https://ufern.net/), including recorded webinars, conference presentations, and publications.  An area of special focus is the assessment of student learning. During the 2019 UFERN network meeting, the UFERN assessment group formed to address the community need for support in collecting empirical evidence about complex student outcomes from UFEs.  This collaborative project group, which included STEM education researchers, social scientists, and undergraduate field educators from multiple disciplines developed a resource for understanding and evaluating outcomes of undergraduate field experiences that was published in an applied journal (Shortlidge et al. 2021). The assessment working group led multiple workshops for faculty based on this work, and now members of this group are supporting the River Field Studies (a currently-funded RCN) to assess their river field courses.  Most importantly, UFERN developed and piloted a system of assessment for use by field educators that is housed and ready to be used on the Center for Improvement of Mentored Experiences in Research (CIMER) platform.

In addition to catalyzing research, the UFERN Model has served as a valuable tool to guide design of student-centered, inclusive UFEs.  The broad flexibility of the model has allowed the field science community to consider the full range of ways that students can engage with "the field" when designing inclusive and welcoming programs and courses. In a professional learning community supported through UFERN, participants reported that the UFERN Model helped them consider various elements as they developed/revised UFEs, such as outdoor constraints, safety, accessibility, and student contextual factors. Although preliminary, a few even reported positive impacts from these applications and dramatic changes in their thinking about UFEs.

Lastly, people are still interested in being involved in UFERN. In the summative evaluation, most of the members indicated that they would remain involved with the network. Many collaborations are ongoing. For example, the Belonging in Field Education project (NSF Award #s 2110824, 2111621) is a direct result of UFERN collaborations and ideas. In the Community of Practice funded by this award, we got 120 applications for 25 spots after sending the opportunity out over the UFERN listserv. Many instructors who applied had been involved in UFERN, and were looking for more opportunities to improve their field teaching.
